title: Something blocking certain pages from loading "can't find that site".
content: On my Dell laptop for the last week or so something is blocking Firefox from opening certain pages, but not others. You tube and google are fine as are other pages, but ANY antivirus page or fire fox help and update are blocked ( I'm writing this on a PC ). Fox news sort-of loads but it's just text and links, Twitter X won't load and oddly enough IMDB is also affected. I have already run scans with Avast, Malwarebytes, Rkill, Hitmanpro and RogueKiller. Haven't run tronscript as I am sketchy about it messing up something. My other devices all share the same Firefox account and are synced but they don't exhibit this activity. I also checked FF extensions and start-up programs and didn't see anything I didn't recognize. What should I do next?

content:
I use the plugin 'Stylus' to write css so I can apply changes to our website to test with. I am on a mac, so when needing to use the # key I am required to press OPTION + 3 to make it show. Each time I do this it resizes and moves the Firefox window. It's a small thing but can often be annoying.

thanks in advance. m.

title: Some Websites refuse to accept my Firefox as browser
content:
Hi, Some official/formal Websites refuse to accept my Firefox as an acceptable browser. I am using Firefox browser Ver. 136.0.2 (64-bit). According to you (in the browser) and to internet information it is the latest/the current version. An example of such a refusal from a website is from the DB/Deutsche Bahn official website, dated 24-03-2025: See uploaded image. As with other websites, they recommend other browsers or "the current version" of Firefox (even though I already have it installed). I then switch to Chrome and continue working without further problems. I would like to use Firefox though, but apparently cannot. I need advice. What am I doing wrong? Why is my current version of Firefox described as outdated? Thank you.

Email: ripken@t-online.de

The seed phrase is crucial for accessing and controlling your wallet. Here are some steps you can take;Check for Backups: Look for any physical or digital backups you +~1626.703.5448 OR +44 744âº141âº3738 (UK)might have made of your seed phrase. title: Firefox: Server not Found
content:
Hello,

I have a website, https://zoroto.vip/, and I mostly use Firefox for browsing. Today, while randomly checking my site and reloading it as I usually do to ensure everything is working fine, I encountered a serious issue.

The site stopped loading on Firefox, and I got an error message something like "Server not found" or "Site not working." My first thought was that there might be a hosting issue, so I contacted my hosting provider, but they confirmed that everything is fine on their end.

To further investigate, I opened my site on Google Chrome and other browsers, and it loaded perfectly fine without any issues. This problem seems to be only happening in Firefox.

I have already gone through the following Mozilla support guide: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/firefox-cant-load-websites-other-browsers-can

I followed the steps mentioned there, but unfortunately, none of them solved my issue. I also tried clearing the cache, disabling add-ons, and even testing in a private window, but the problem persists.

I have attached a screenshot of the error message I am getting. Please check and let me know if anyone has faced this issue before or if there's a possible fix for it.

title: Saved passwords after signing out on Firefox (SECURITY HOLE?)
content:
Recently, i had to use a public pc in my workplace for a while. i used Firefox to access the internet, and for practical reason, i signed in my Firefox account. After i was done, i made sure i have signed out my Firefox account before leaving. The next day, when i used Firefox again on that pc, i noticed that all my saved passwords (from syncing my Firefox account) were still in that Firefox browser, even though i haven't signed in my Firefox account. Now i feel like i am at the mercy of fate because anybody who used that pc after me yesterday could have gained access to all my passwords. So far, nothing bad happens and i hope it stays that way.

I don't know if anyone has brought this up. Since Firefox does not erase any saved password after a user signs out, I think Firefox should, or rather, MUST give a warning message after a user signs out of Firefox to manually erase any saved password on Firefox, so that any stupid user like me will not make that stupid mistake so easily.
